page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Hosni Mubarak's rule

rev.diff:
Line 226: Line 226:
===5 February===
===5 February===
â
[[File:Broadcast of the revolution.jpg|thumb|The so-called ''Etha'et al-thawra'' (broadcast of the revolution), set upon an elevated stage and used by the demonstrators in Tahrir Square to address the crowds. In the background is the [[American University in Cairo]].]]
 
[[File:'You shall rise' Egyptian Revolution.png|thumb|left|Egyptian protesters holding the Egyptian flag with one hand while showing the [[V sign]] with the other]]
[[File:'You shall rise' Egyptian Revolution.png|thumb|left|Egyptian protesters holding the Egyptian flag with one hand while showing the [[V sign]] with the other]]
  +
[[File:Broadcast of the revolution.jpg|thumb|The so-called ''Etha'et al-thawra'' (broadcast of the revolution), set upon an elevated stage and used by the demonstrators in Tahrir Square to address the crowds. In the background is the [[American University in Cairo]].]]
During the night of 4â5 February, a few protesters continued to camp out in Tahrir Square, though it was largely quiet. Early in the morning shots were fired as protesters said pro-Mubarak activists tried to assault the square. Troops then fired into the air to disperse them. Demonstrators later formed a human chain to prevent tanks from passing through the barricades into the square; a witness said scuffles broke out when an army general asked demonstrators to take down their make-shift barricades of corrugated steel and debris.<ref name="CNN 5 Feb">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/05/egypt.protests/index.html?hpt=T1|title=Egypt's government meets opposition as protests continue|newspaper=[[CNN]]|author=CNN Wire Staff|date=February 5, 2011|accessdate=February 5, 2011}}</ref> As the army tightened access to Tahrir Square, the head of the army met protesters<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/05/us-egypt-protests-idUSTRE7141S820110205 |title=Egypt army seeks to free Tahrir Square for traffic |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2011-04-08}}. Reuters. Retrieved on 2011-04-08.</ref> and asked them to return home. Protesters responded that "he (Mubarak) will go" and they would not. The army was also more organised and present than on any other day of the protest.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/04/live-blog-feb-5-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 5 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref> A heavy military presence continued in central Cairo. An Interior Ministry spokesman said that "the army remains neutral and is not taking sides because if we protect one side we will be perceived as biased....our role is to prevent clashes and chaos as we separate the opposing groups."<ref name="CNN 5 Feb" /> Scuffles were reported during the day in Tahrir Square and one protester was said to have died. A group of foreigners including an English protester on the 5th and a Swede on the 6th<ref>{{cite web|url=http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Swedish_protester_in_Tahrir.jpg |title=File:Swedish protester in Tahrir.jpg - Wikimedia Commons |publisher=Commons.wikimedia.org |date=2011-02-06 |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref> joined the protesters in Tahrir Square, handing out flowers in a sign of solidarity and holding up a banner in English. Five hundred protesters arrived in Tahrir Square from Suez. There were reports of over 10,000 people continuing to stay in Alexandria through the night.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb" />
During the night of 4â5 February, a few protesters continued to camp out in Tahrir Square, though it was largely quiet. Early in the morning shots were fired as protesters said pro-Mubarak activists tried to assault the square. Troops then fired into the air to disperse them. Demonstrators later formed a human chain to prevent tanks from passing through the barricades into the square; a witness said scuffles broke out when an army general asked demonstrators to take down their make-shift barricades of corrugated steel and debris.<ref name="CNN 5 Feb">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/05/egypt.protests/index.html?hpt=T1|title=Egypt's government meets opposition as protests continue|newspaper=[[CNN]]|author=CNN Wire Staff|date=February 5, 2011|accessdate=February 5, 2011}}</ref> As the army tightened access to Tahrir Square, the head of the army met protesters<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/05/us-egypt-protests-idUSTRE7141S820110205 |title=Egypt army seeks to free Tahrir Square for traffic |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2011-04-08}}. Reuters. Retrieved on 2011-04-08.</ref> and asked them to return home. Protesters responded that "he (Mubarak) will go" and they would not. The army was also more organised and present than on any other day of the protest.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/04/live-blog-feb-5-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 5 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref> A heavy military presence continued in central Cairo. An Interior Ministry spokesman said that "the army remains neutral and is not taking sides because if we protect one side we will be perceived as biased....our role is to prevent clashes and chaos as we separate the opposing groups."<ref name="CNN 5 Feb" /> Scuffles were reported during the day in Tahrir Square and one protester was said to have died. A group of foreigners including an English protester on the 5th and a Swede on the 6th<ref>{{cite web|url=http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Swedish_protester_in_Tahrir.jpg |title=File:Swedish protester in Tahrir.jpg - Wikimedia Commons |publisher=Commons.wikimedia.org |date=2011-02-06 |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref> joined the protesters in Tahrir Square, handing out flowers in a sign of solidarity and holding up a banner in English. Five hundred protesters arrived in Tahrir Square from Suez. There were reports of over 10,000 people continuing to stay in Alexandria through the night.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb" />
